post_content:
Title: Revolutionizing Healthcare in Southeast Asia with AI-Powered Chatbots

Introduction

In recent years, chatbots have evolved beyond their simple, predetermined reply roots. The incorporation of large language models has made them increasingly useful, particularly in industries where informed decisions are crucial. One such industry is healthcare, and Thailand-based HD is at the forefront of this revolution. By harnessing the power of generative AI, HD is developing custom chatbots to cater to the unique needs of the healthcare sector in Southeast Asia.

The Need for Conversational AI in Healthcare

HD started as a marketplace for third-party healthcare and surgery services. Co-founder Sheji Ho recognized the potential of conversational AI in the healthcare customer journey, as people often prefer to ask questions before making a purchase, especially when it comes to hospital services. With 90% of chat messages on HD's marketplace inquiring about product information, there was a clear need for an advanced, AI-driven solution to streamline the process and enhance customer experience.

Securing Investments for AI Development

To advance its AI ambitions, HD recently raised a $5.6 million Series A round led by SBI Ven Capital, a subsidiary of the Japanese financial giant SBI Group. This investment will enable HD to build what it calls the "Sierra AI of the Southeast Asian healthcare industry." By leveraging its accumulated transaction, chat, FAQ, and product catalog data, HD aims to create highly-specialized, vertical AI tailored to the healthcare sector.

Focusing on Local Data and Vertical AI

HD recognizes that it cannot compete with U.S. firms in terms of resources, such as access to powerful GPUs, talent, and venture capital. Instead, the company is focusing on building vertical AI with local data as its moat. By using proprietary data that no one else has, HD plans to create an AI application that is both practical and monetizable.

post_title: The US and UK are teaming up to test the safety of AI models
title:
AI Safety Partnership: US & UK Unite for Testing Advanced Models

Or

US-UK AI Safety Institute Collaboration for Responsible Technology
post_content:
Title: Global Collaboration for AI Safety: A New Era of Responsible Technology

The development and release of increasingly sophisticated large language models by companies such as OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic have prompted the UK and US governments to join forces. In a bid to establish a unified approach to evaluating the safety of advanced AI models, they have signed a Memorandum of Understanding. This partnership brings together the UK's AI Safety Institute and its yet-to-be-named US counterpart, with the goal of creating test suites to assess risks and ensure safety.

Key aspects of this collaboration include:

1. Sharing technical knowledge, information, and personnel to facilitate joint testing exercises on publicly accessible models.
2. Prioritizing the evaluation of the next generation of AI models, which are expected to be "game-changers" with uncertain capabilities.

This groundbreaking partnership marks the first bilateral agreement on AI safety between countries, with both the US and the UK expressing intentions to collaborate with additional nations in the future. As stated by US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo, "AI is the defining technology of our generation... Our partnership will accelerate both of our Institutes' work across the full spectrum of risks, whether to our national security or to our broader society."

Governments worldwide are taking steps to regulate AI tools and ensure their safety. In March, the White House signed an executive order to guarantee that federal agencies use AI tools that "do not endanger the rights and safety of the American people." Similarly, the European Parliament approved legislation to regulate artificial intelligence, targeting AI that manipulates human behavior, exploits vulnerabilities, or employs biometric categorization. Moreover, deepfakes and other AI-generated content will require clear labeling under these new rules.

In summary, international cooperation and regulation are vital in the rapidly evolving landscape of AI technology. The UK-US partnership represents a significant stride in ensuring the safety and ethical use of advanced AI models, paving the way for a more responsible approach to this groundbreaking technology. As governments continue to develop regulations, the emphasis on safety and ethical considerations will foster trust and confidence in AI applications, driving innovation while protecting the rights and well-being of individuals worldwide.

post_title: Researchers build selenium-silicon tandem solar cell that could improve efficiency to 40%
title: Tandem solar cells: Selenium and silicon combined for higher efficiency
post_content:
The world is moving towards renewable energy sources, and solar cells have emerged as a game-changer in this field. However, despite their advantages, solar cells still have a lot of room for improvement. In fact, they currently capture only about 27% of the energy in the sunlight that strikes them, which is close to the theoretical limit for such technology. To address this issue, researchers at Technical University of Denmark have developed a promising new approach to solar cell design: a monolithic selenium/silicon tandem solar cell.

In this study, the researchers demonstrated that it is possible to build a working tandem solar cell that combines the advantages of both selenium and silicon. Selenium is a semiconducting material that was used to make solar cells before scientists discovered that silicon was more suitable. However, it has different photon-absorbing properties, which allows for the creation of a dual-material solar cell. Furthermore, selenium has a wide bandgap, which makes it an ideal material for high-efficiency solar cells.

To create the tandem cell, the researchers started with a standard silicon base, added some oxide layers, and then added a thin film of selenium. They then placed the cell in sunlight and measured its performance. The results were promising: the tandem cell was able to generate 1.68 volts of electricity and had a conversion efficiency of 2.7%. These numbers are already impressive, but the researchers believe that the cell's efficiency could be increased by ten times simply by improving resistance.

The researchers' calculations suggest that with further refinement, the tandem cell could achieve an efficiency rating of approximately 40%. This would be a major breakthrough in the field of solar cell technology, as it would bring us much closer to the theoretical limit for such devices.

The research team's monolithic selenium/silicon tandem solar cell is a promising new approach to solar cell design that combines the advantages of both selenium and silicon. With further refinement, this technology could lead to a significant increase in the efficiency of solar cells, bringing us closer to a future powered by renewable energy sources.

post_title: Research team creates biofilm-resistant glass for marine environments
title: UV Glass: Revolutionary Biofilm-Resistant Material for Marine Environments
post_content:
Title: Glowing Glass: A Revolutionary Solution to Biofilm Growth in Underwater Environments

Introduction

Imagine a world where underwater surfaces remain consistently clean and free from harmful biofilm growth. A team of engineers from the University of Massachusetts Amherst has developed ultraviolet (UV) rays-emitting glass capable of reducing 98% of biofilm from developing on submerged surfaces. This breakthrough technology offers a promising alternative to chemical-based methods, which often have negative environmental impacts and limited durability.

The Biofilm Problem

Biofilm is a slimy layer of various microorganisms that adheres to wet surfaces. It poses significant challenges in underwater applications, leading to increased drag, fuel usage, corrosion damage, and even the transportation of non-native species across seas. Current solutions include biocidal coatings and nonstick coatings; however, these methods have limitations, such as their short-lived effectiveness, potential harm to ecosystems, and high maintenance costs.

UV Rays-Emitting Glass: A Game Changer

The UMass Amherst researchers, led by Mariana Lanzarini-Lopes, have harnessed the power of UVC radiation, the shortest and most effective at disinfecting wavelength of UV radiation, to create a revolutionary biofilm-resistant glass. This glass, when treated with ultraviolet rays, demonstrates 98% less biofilm growth compared to untreated glass.

The Science Behind the Technology

UV side-emitting optical fiber has already proven effective in distributing UVC radiation in small channels, such as medical equipment, home devices, and water storage/distribution systems. However, the challenge of evenly distributing UV light in underwater environments remains. To address this, the team developed a silica-nanoparticle coating on the glass to scatter the UV light evenly across the surface, creating a uniform "glowing" effect.

Real-World Testing and Applications

The researchers submerged the UV-emitting glass in the waters of Port Canaveral, Florida for 20 days, observing a 98% reduction in visible biofilm growth compared to untreated glass. With potential applications in various industries, the UV-emitting glass technology can be used for disinfecting transparent surfaces such as windows

title: Rubrik's IPO hints at thawing public markets for tech companies
post_content:
Cleaned Instructions:
Rubrik, a data cybersecurity company that raised more than half a billion dollars while private, filed to go public after the bell on Monday. Following closely on the heels of debuts from Reddit and Astera Labs, the choice by Rubrik to pursue a public offering now could indicate that the IPO market is warming for tech companies.

As a private-market company, Rubrik last raised a lettered round in 2019 when it closed $261 million at a $3.3 billion post-money valuation, according to Crunchbase data. The company could have luck pricing its IPO shares significantly higher than its last primary round. Buyers on the secondary market have bid for shares valuing the company at $6.6 billion in recent months. Secondary data platform Caplight estimates the company’s valuation hovers around $6.3 billion.

Rubrik sells its cloud-based data protection platform to enterprises. As of January, the company had over 1,700 customers with an annual contract value of $100,000 and nearly 100 customers who paid Rubrik over $1 million a year, according to its IPO filing.

Rubrik's Growth
Rubrik initially presents as a moderately growing software business with net losses that stretched to $354 million in its most recent fiscal year.

From its fiscal 2023 to its fiscal 2024, which concluded at the end of January this year, the company’s revenue grew from $599.8 million to $627.9 million, or just under 5%. However, subscription revenue grew 40% over the same period, rising from $385.3 million to $537.9 million.

The growth in its subscription revenue, and not its legacy revenues, is the engine that could propel Rubrik to a successful IPO. The company began life as a software company that sold its product on a perpetual license basis. However, after several years, it began to shift toward a subscription model in its fiscal 2019. It expanded its subscription (SaaS) offerings over time and told investors in its IPO filing that it anticipates that its non-recurring revenues will “continue to decrease,” as it doesn’t generally offer perpetual licenses today.

Rubrik’s transformation to recurring revenues is nearing its completion, with the company reporting that in its most recent quarter — the period ending January 31, 2024 — subscription-related top line comprised 91% of its total revenue. That was up from 73% in the year-ago quarter.

The business model transition from licenses to SaaS can be costly and has weighed on stock prices of other large security companies like Splunk, said Brendan Burke, emerging technology analyst at PitchBook. “Yet Rubrik shares have traded at a 50% premium to the last VC round in secondary markets, suggesting the company will be able to justify a sufficiently high valuation to fund this shift,” he said.

The shift to subscription revenue has helped Rubrik boost its gross margins, which rose from 70% in its fiscal 2023 to 77% in its recently completed fiscal 2024.

However, a growing recurring-revenue software business and improving gross margins have not solved Rubrik’s stiff losses. The company’s net losses grew from 46% of revenue in its fiscal 2023 to 56% in its fiscal 2024, totaling some $354.2 million in the 12 months ending January 31, 2024.

However, despite Rubrik’s steep unprofitability, its cash burn has been comparatively modest. The difference between its net losses and operating cash deficits is not resolved through the excision of expansive share-based compensation; those are single-digit million yearly expenses at the company. title: Agile Space Industries: Revolutionizing US Rocket Engine Testing with Animas
post_content:
Title: Agile Space Industries: Revolutionizing Rocket Engine Testing in the US

Introduction

The space industry has experienced remarkable growth over the past decade, yet the number of testing facilities for rocket and spacecraft engines in the US remains limited. This scarcity poses a challenge for smaller companies, which must endure lengthy wait times and high costs. Agile Space Industries, founded by Daudi Barnes in 2019, aims to disrupt this status quo. Expanding from the work of Advanced Mobile Propulsion Test (AMPT), Agile now focuses on propulsion systems, thrusters, rocket engines, and ground support equipment.

The Dawn of Agile Space Industries

Agile Space Industries operates two test stands: Sunshine, established in 2010 by AMPT, and the recently inaugurated Animas. This new test stand is particularly noteworthy, as it is the only commercial facility capable of vacuum testing hypergolic engines with more than 300 pounds and up to 6,000 pounds of thrust, according to the company.

Addressing a Growing Market

Graham Dudley, the Animas project manager, explains, "The market is just really, really expanding right now... For testing though? It’s really, really hard to do." Animas stands out for its modularity, allowing it to be used for various test campaigns, from early prototype testing to qualification and acceptance testing. This flexibility enables Agile to cater to a diverse range of customer needs.

The Importance of Engine Testing

Engine testing not only provides Agile with an additional revenue stream but also accelerates in-house engine development. Mesa Hollinbeck, Agile's lead test engineer, highlights the benefits of early access to testing: "Being able to have easy access to testing earlier in your programs is really helpful... Having access to testing early is definitely a problem for a lot of the industry."

Vacuum Testing: A Crucial Element

Vacuum testing is essential for in-space propulsion systems, as it simulates the space environment. However, smaller NewSpace companies often find this testing prohibitively expensive. Agile's ownership of the test bed ensures its engineers have access to valuable data on their systems, providing a competitive edge in the increasingly crowded space propulsion market.

Title: Google's DBSC: A New Line of Defense Against Cookie Theft

Introduction

In the digital world, internet cookies play a crucial role in enhancing user experience by storing site preferences and browsing information. However, they also pose a risk as they can be used to track users or even be stolen by malicious actors. Google has recently unveiled an innovative solution to combat this issue: Device Bound Session Credentials (DBSC). This new technology aims to protect users against malware that steals cookies, thus reducing the chances of cookie theft and account compromise.

Understanding DBSC

DBSC is a security measure developed by Google to protect users against cookie theft malware. Attackers typically steal authentication cookies from browsers on your device and move them to remote servers, which they then sell for illicit purposes. DBSC is designed to significantly reduce the occurrence of cookie theft by forcing attackers to act locally on the device, making it easier for antivirus software and managed devices to detect and eliminate threats.

Development and Rollout

Google is developing DBSC in the open on GitHub, where it has also shared a timeline for its rollout. The ultimate goal is to conduct an origin trial in Chrome by the end of 2024. Currently, Google is testing a DBSC prototype to protect some Google Account users running Chrome beta. This test aims to assess DBSC's reliability and feasibility before rolling it out to consumer and enterprise Chrome users via an automatic update.

Implications for Cybersecurity

DBSC is a promising development in the fight against cybercrime. By making it more difficult for attackers to steal cookies, DBSC can significantly reduce the success rate of cookie theft malware. Moreover, it can help improve the effectiveness of antivirus software and managed devices in detecting and eliminating threats.

Conclusion

Google's DBSC is an innovative solution to combat cookie theft and protect users' online accounts. By forcing attackers to act locally on the device, DBSC makes it easier for antivirus software and managed devices to detect and eliminate threats. With DBSC, Google continues to demonstrate its commitment to enhancing cybersecurity and protecting users' online privacy. As DBSC moves towards its origin trial in Chrome, users can look forward to a safer and more secure browsing experience.

Do you want to power your IoT devices with ambient energy? Look no further than electrostatic generators. These innovative devices harness energy from environmental sources like wind and human motion to power low-power devices in IoT networks. A groundbreaking study published in the journal Microsystems & Nanoengineering introduces an energy management unit (EMU) designed to significantly boost the power efficiency of electrostatic generators for IoT devices. This innovation addresses the longstanding challenge of impedance mismatch, paving the way for using environmental energy harvesting within the IoT domain.

The research team has achieved an unprecedented direct current output of 79.2 mW m-2 rps-1 in rotary electret generators, marking a significant leap in efficiency. Furthermore, the EMU increased the performance of contact-separated triboelectric nanogenerators by 50%, demonstrating its versatility across different energy-harvesting technologies.

This advancement stems from the meticulous optimization of critical components, such as the spark-switch tube and buck converter, which propelled direct current power generation to new heights. This progress not only surpasses existing energy efficiency benchmarks but also underscores the EMU's compatibility with a wide array of generator designs.

Zeyuan Cao, co-author of the study, states, "Our work represents a significant step towards the practical application of electrostatic generators in IoT devices. By optimizing our EMU, we've achieved unprecedented efficiency, making self-powered IoT devices more viable than ever."

This breakthrough not only enhances the efficiency and reliability of self-powered IoT devices but also facilitates their broader adoption in sustainable and remote applications. It heralds a new era of energy autonomy within the IoT landscape, marking a significant advancement in the realm of environmental energy harvesting for IoT applications.

To address these challenges, Home From College offers a platform where students can find gigs that are tailored to their busy schedules and provide valuable experience related to their career goals. Rather than applying for unpaid internships, they can take on side hustles that interest them, such as becoming a social media ambassador or logo designer. One of the unique features of Home From College is its interview feature, where students can answer questions from real companies and showcase their skills and personality. post_title: Anthropic researchers wear down AI ethics with repeated questions
title: LLM Vulnerability: "Many-Shot Jailbreaking" Exploited by Anthropic Researchers
post_content:
Introduction:

In recent years, we have seen a significant increase in the use of large language models (LLMs) in various applications, including language translation, chatbots, and content generation. However, as with any new technology, there are always risks associated with it, and researchers are constantly working to identify and mitigate them. In this article, we will explore a new vulnerability that has been discovered in LLMs, known as "many-shot jailbreaking."

Body:

Many-shot jailbreaking is a technique that allows an LLM to be convinced to perform a task it was not designed for, by first being primed with a series of less harmful questions. This technique takes advantage of the increased "context window" of the latest generation of LLMs, which allows them to hold more data in short-term memory. What Anthropic's researchers found was that LLMs with large context windows tend to perform better on many tasks if there are lots of examples of that task within the prompt.

In an unexpected extension of this "in-context learning," LLMs also become "better" at replying to inappropriate questions. So, if you ask an LLM to build a bomb right away, it will refuse. But if you ask it to answer 99 other questions of lesser harmfulness and then ask it to build a bomb, it's much more likely to comply.

The reason for this behavior is not entirely clear, but it appears that LLMs have some mechanism that allows them to home in on what the user wants, as evidenced by the content in the context window. If the user wants trivia, for example, LLMs seem to gradually activate more latent trivia power as you ask dozens of questions. And for some reason, the same thing happens with users asking for dozens of inappropriate answers.

The team that discovered this vulnerability has already informed their peers and competitors about it, hoping to foster a culture where exploits like this are openly shared among LLM providers and researchers. For their own mitigation, they found that although limiting the context window helps, it also has a negative effect on the model's performance. So they are working on classifying and contextualizing queries before they go to the model.

Conclusion:

Many-shot jailbreaking is a new vulnerability that has been discovered in LLMs, which allows them to be convinced to perform a task they were not designed for by first being primed with a series of less harmful questions. The vulnerability takes advantage of the increased context window of the latest generation of LLMs and has the potential to be exploited for malicious purposes. However, researchers are working to mitigate the vulnerability by developing new techniques and approaches to ensure that LLMs are used responsibly and securely.

title: "NHS Provides Artificial Pancreas to Thousands of Type 1 Diabetes Patients in England"
post_content:
The National Health Service (NHS) in England has announced that it will be providing an artificial pancreas system to tens of thousands of children and adults with type 1 diabetes. The hybrid closed loop system, which involves a sensor under the skin that sends wireless readings to an externally worn pump that delivers insulin as needed, can help patients manage their insulin levels without the need for finger sticks or injections.

This isn't the first device of its kind. Tandem makes a similar insulin pump in the US after it received FDA authorization in 2019. Gizmodo notes that another company called iLet also received FDA approval for a similar device last year. However, what sets the NHS program apart is that it will provide these devices for free to all eligible patients rather than as an exclusive privilege for the well-to-do.

The hybrid closed loop system works by implanting a sensor under the skin that continually monitors glucose levels at regular intervals. The sensor sends that data wirelessly to a pump, worn externally, which delivers the proper insulin dosage. The “hybrid” part of its name comes from the fact that some user input, including entering carb intake, is still required in the otherwise self-regulating system.

The NHS estimates that 269,095 people in England live with type 1 diabetes, highlighting how many individuals could potentially benefit from the program. Local branches of the NHS will begin identifying patients for the program on Tuesday.

Colette Marshall, chief executive of Diabetes UK, wrote in the NHS's press release announcing the rollout, “Diabetes is a tough and relentless condition, but these systems make a significant, life-changing difference — improving both the overall health and quality of life for people with diabetes. This really is a landmark moment, and we’ll be working with the NHS and others to ensure a fair rollout that reaches people as quickly as possible.”

This new development is a game-changer for people with type 1 diabetes in England, providing them with a more convenient and effective way to manage their condition.

Introduction

In the quest for safer and more efficient energy storage solutions, scientists have long been exploring the potential of solid-state lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries with solid electrolytes. These batteries offer several advantages over their conventional counterparts, including higher energy density, improved transference numbers, and non-flammability. However, solid electrolytes often face challenges such as lower Li-ion conductivity and poor electrode-solid electrolyte contact. Moreover, sulfide-based solid electrolytes, which are highly conductive, can react with moisture and form toxic hydrogen disulfide, posing safety concerns. A new design for a liquid-solid triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) improves energy harvesting from waves. The TENG converts mechanical energy into electricity as water sloshes back and forth against the inside of the tube. The device was previously limited by its low energy output.

post_title: SaaS entrepreneur Raisinghani's new AI venture nabs $5.5M to boost sales efficiency
title: SiftHub: An AI Assistant for Sales and Presales Teams - Boosts Sales Efficiency with $5.5M Funding
post_content:
Title: SiftHub: An AI Assistant for Sales and Presales Teams

Introduction:

SiftHub, an AI startup founded by Manisha Raisinghani, has raised $5.5 million in seed funding to build out its AI assistant for sales and presales teams. The company's generative AI assistant is aimed at helping teams focus more on building relationships and less on grunt work.

Body:

SiftHub's AI assistant is designed to tackle the bulk of non-sales activity that sales personnel have to deal with, such as entering data into CRM systems, filing requests for proposals (RFPs), researching customer information, and building presentation decks. The assistant integrates with sources of information like Google Drive, Slack, Zendesk, HubSpot, and Salesforce, and sales and presales teams can simply talk to it to complete infosec questionnaires, vendor assessment forms, and file RFPs and request for information (RFI) forms.

The assistant is available through Slack and Microsoft Teams as a bot, as a Microsoft add-in, a Chrome plugin, and a web app, and has support for 10 languages, including Spanish and German. SiftHub's AI assistant is built on open-source large language models (LLMs), and is supported by retrieval augmented generation (RAG) technology, which uses additional data sources to fine-tune the quality of content generated by AI. This helps the startup limit hallucinations, a common issue with generative AI, where the system generates incorrect or misleading results.

Cross-encoders are also used by SiftHub to prevent its platform from picking the wrong information from a given knowledge base. Cross-encoders analyze two queries simultaneously, instead of looking at each separately, to deliver more accurate answers. SiftHub's system might give 5% fewer answers, but the founder is confident that at least 75% of the AI's responses will be correct.

SiftHub also uses a "smart search algorithm" that considers the recency of documents or knowledge sources to surface relevant recent information. The startup is headquartered in the U.S., with an R&D team in Mumbai, India.

Conclusion:

SiftHub's AI assistant is a valuable tool for sales and presales teams, as it allows them to focus more on building relationships and less on grunt work. The startup's use of open-source large language models and retrieval augmented generation technology ensures the accuracy and quality of the information generated by the AI assistant. With the $5.5 million seed funding, SiftHub plans to hire more people in product R&D, enhance the product, and help the company go to market.

This assault on human creativity must be stopped. We must protect against the predatory use of AI to steal professional artists' voices and likenesses, violate creators' rights, and destroy the music ecosystem."
